title: Soldiering On Awards 2017: Veterans with Dogs soothing 'invisible injuries' of soldiers
text:
Without veterans with dogs I wouldn’t be able to take my children out as I wouldn’t leave the house Veteran 
The way a dog can become a comrade for a veteran, helping with every day challenges such as turning on lights or giving support during a panic attack, highlights how precious bonds are formed and lives changed by a loyal, devoted and well trained animal. 
Veterans with Dogs was founded with the intention of training fully accredited and recognised assistance canines to help mitigate the symptoms of mental health difficulties for former military personnel as well as those still on active duty. 
VWD have now been nominated as part of the Soldiering On Awards 2017 which salutes the special relationship between animals and serving military personnel and veterans. NC VWD was founded by Craig MacLellan who has a fully-qualified assistance dog called Boo 
Express readers are today invited to play their part honouring this special covenant by voting for the worthy recipient of the Pets at Home Animal Partnership Award. 
The suffering veterans bear can be heavy. 
More die from suicides because of psychological and emotional trauma than are killed in conflict. 
Others endure divorce, homelessness and imprisonment. 
There are the recurring nightmares and the fear of stepping into the outside world. 
Working as a team with a specially trained dog gives a veteran the gift of independence, increasing leisure and social participation, and helping them face stressful moments with less anxiety. 
For the handler, training a dog requires commitment and an understanding that results are achieved slowly, but are both fun and rewarding as bonds are forged. 
The charity said: “VWD uses positive, gentle training methods to achieve our goals. 
“The end product is a team: a person and a dog working together happily, totally in-tune and understanding each other completely.” VWD VWD VWD uses positive, gentle training methods 
There is no charge for providing and training of a VWD assistance dog, although responsibility for keeping the animal and paying for its daily care falls on to the handler once it has been placed. 
It is a small price. As one veteran explains: “Without veterans with dogs I wouldn’t be able to take my children out as I wouldn’t leave the house. 
“Everyone was walking on egg Shells. With the arrival of my dog, Scout, and the help and support of Veterans with Dogs, I am able to go about life as normally as it can be with invisible wounds. Animal Rescuer of the Year Awards Sun, October 26, 2014
